video.title: ASP.NET Core Crash Course - C# App in One Hour
video.description:
Learn how to create a web database app in ASP.NET Core using Visual Studio and the C# language.

This tutorial will show you how to :
- Use the MVC (Model View Controller) design pattern.
- Configure database tables using the Entity framework.
- Setup of classes as models. Customize Razor forms.
- Create methods inside a controller.
- Style an ASP.NET page with CSS.
- Use Bootstrap classes.
- Create a search function to filter database results.

✏️ Course developed by Shad Sluiter. Check out his YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/user/shadsluiter

⭐️ Special thanks to our Champion supporters! ⭐️ 
🏆 Loc Do
🏆 Joseph C
🏆 DeezMaster

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Chris Rowe
topLevelComment.text: This almost feels like cheating. I've been doing Javascript/Typescript and Node back ends using a "sequelize" npm for my ORM, and then making all of my views myself in one of the popular JS frameworks. I just got hired for my first full time dev role working with C#, .NET, & Blazor so I wanted to follow this to get my feet wet. It's unbelievable how much hard work and time has gone into creating this tooling. I know that this is still something that is good to understand what is happening under the hood with, and that obviously, any sort of consumer-facing finished project in production would need a lot more configuring and styling but I am blown away at how quickly this tutorial took me from no application, to a working CRUD + DB app. Great video!

replies.author: Matty Ice
replies.text: @Adam On Journey I just now partially got your answer and found that the jokes db resides in "SQL Server Object Explorer" and not in "Server Explorer". Thanks much. So the next question is why does EF choose SQL Server Object Explorer instead  of Server Explorer and why doesnt MS SQL Server Management Studio show these tables?

replies.author: Adam On Journey
replies.text: Ok, you could hardcode all jokes, but you will loose the flexibility of edit, create and delete.... you always have to go into your code to change your jokes and deploy your app again... or change a dll... whatever, not the modern way of programming..

replies.author: Adam On Journey
replies.text: @Matty Ice No, you always need a place, where you can store your data: a server or a local database, if you need some management or very small solutions like xml-files... csv or whatever. You could save your data in an temporary object,  for sure... but you would loose your data after every app stop... so this tutorial shows one of those possibilities... a local database.

replies.author: Matty Ice
replies.text: @Adam On Journey sort of off topic, but will this jokesapp work without a local sql server installation? Just Visual studio + .net core + etc... but no SQL Server? Totally apologize if this is a dumb question, I will look it up myself.

replies.author: Adam On Journey
replies.text: If you want to to find out how: Visual Studio: Menu -> View, then you find Server-Explorer and SQL-Server-Objekt-Explorer, the latter one is that one you need now. If you choose first, the is a violett button at top of this view to change views to the object Explorer. Then you get this view, which was showed in this tutorial. Right-Click at the JokeWebAppDataBase, at bottom click Properties... , you see at the right side of VS the Property-Window now and just look around to find your path. VS has since years a bug in naming the path of thelocaldatabase: It should be c:\users\YourName\345345manyNumbers.mdf, buuuut it is always: c:\users\yourname345345manynumbers.mdf, because for some boring reason the "\" between folder users and folder YourName is missing. SO go to folder: c\users... there you will find then your database. At some other tutorials my database was inside the app-folders... but you will find the path, if you read the properties as written above! Have fun and stay patient!
